Dependent origination instead views the change as being caused by many factors, not just one or even a few. Those dharmas which arise from a cause, the TathÄgata has declared their cause. And that which is the cessation of them, thus the great renunciant (sramana) has taught. Through ignorance, karma is accumulated, karma is the cause of (re)birth. Through knowledge, karma is not accumulated, through absence of karma, one is not (re)born. The additional verse is Southeast Asia specific (fifth century date) and does not have an equivalent in any Buddhist text, whether in the original Indic language or Tibetan or Chinese translation. Karma is like a very long personal balance sheet, where good karma is an asset and bad karma is a liability. We are born as human being because of karma debts and we need to pay those off.

Paying off karma debts comes with the benefit of reducing the risk of karma due at unexpected times. Not to mention that being reborn as a human being is not a guarantee. When some of the karma debts are paid off, we contribute towards the permanent cessation of suffering. It is indeed possible to end the cycle of suffering (nirodha), and to attain a state of inner peace and freedom (nibbÄna).
The most practical way to pay off karma debts is through liberation prayers. (e.g. Ä€ryatÄrÄ Atiyoga)

Buddhism helped us answer a lot of questions like: Why are we born in certain families? Why do we meet some group of people? Why are we born at all? What's the purpose of our life? Why are we dying? The answer to those questions is all our own doing. We caused all those and are in full control of our own decisions and lives. The benefit of paying off karma debts outweighs the risk of not doing it. Life as a human being is precious because it gives us a better opportunity to pay off our karma debts. A pig would have a harder time doing liberation prayer. It is easy to doubt the law of kamma. We see so many people who do good deeds and seem to gain no benefit. So many people do bad things and become rich and successful. The Buddha said that the results of kamma will only appear rapidly if the surroundings allow it. For example, a corrupt person in a corrupt environment will receive the kammic results of his bad actions much more slowly than a corrupt person in an environment that values honesty. Sooner or later, however, the results will manifest. Most important to note is that every time that we act with a good, kind, noble intention then those qualities are immediately strengthened in our hearts. And so with selfish, cruel intentions. This strengthening of good and bad qualities in the heart is the perceivable result of kamma, which we do not merely believe in, but can see for ourselves. -- Ajahn JayasÄro Buddha says common sense and logical thinking are insufficient to determine the truth. We can be sure of what to follow, only through our own experience or the experience of the wise ones. â€œNow, KÄlÄmas, donâ€™t go by reports, by legends, by traditions, by scripture, by logical conjecture, by inference, by analogies, by agreement through pondering views, by probability, or by the thought, â€˜This contemplative is our teacher.â€™ When you know for yourselves that, â€˜These qualities are skillful; these qualities are blameless; these qualities are praised by the observant; these qualities, when adopted & carried out, lead to welfare & to happinessâ€™â€” then you should enter & remain in them. -- Kalama Sutta The Buddha proceeds to list the criteria by which any sensible person can decide which teachings to accept as true. Do not blindly believe religious teachings, just because they are claimed to be true, or even through the application of various methods or techniques. Direct knowledge grounded in one's own experience can be called upon. The Buddha proposes not a passive acceptance but, rather, constant questioning and personal testing to identify those truths which verifiably reduce one's own suffering or misery (dukkha).

Buddhism does not focus on God but rather on ourselves. Buddha is not a God but a spiritual teacher. We are the one who accumulates bad karma, and we are the one who has the responsibility to pay for it. If we took a mortgage, we don't expect Buddha or God to pay for it, do we?

Dependent on ignorance, arises formations. Dependent on formations, arises consciousness. Dependent on consciousness, arises mentality-materiality. Dependent on mentality-materiality, arise the six-sense bases. Dependent on the six-sense bases, arises contact. Dependent on contact, arises feeling. Dependent on feeling, arises craving. Dependent on craving, arises clinging. Dependent on clinging, arises the arranging of kamma. Dependent on the arranging of kamma, arises birth. Dependent on birth, arises aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief and despair. Thus, there is the arising of this whole mass of suffering. Through the entire cessation of ignorance, formations cease. Through the cessation of formations, consciousness ceases. Through the cessation of consciousness, mentality-materiality ceases. Through the cessation of mentality-materiality, the six-sense bases cease. Through the cessation of the six-sense bases, contact ceases. Through the cessation of contact, feeling ceases. Through the cessation of feeling, craving ceases. Through the cessation of craving, clinging ceases. Through the cessation of clinging, the arranging of kamma ceases. Through the cessation of the arranging of kamma, birth ceases. Through the cessation of birth, aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief and despair ceases. Thus, there is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering. à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§ à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¾-à¤ªà¤šà¥à¤šà¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¤¾à¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ ye dharmÄ hetuprabhavÄ hetuá¹ƒ teá¹£Äá¹ƒ tathÄgata uvÄca à¥¤ teá¹£Äá¹ƒ-ca yo nirodha evaá¹ƒvÄdi mahÄÅ›ramaá¹‡aá¸¥ à¥¤ ajÃ±ÄnÄc cÄ«yate karma janmanaá¸¥ karma kÄraá¹‡am à¥¤ jÃ±ÄnÄn na cÄ«yate karma karmÄbhÄvÄn na jÄyateà¥¥ 7x Dependent origination can be contrasted with the classic Western concept of causation in which an action by one thing is said to cause a change in another thing. Dependent origination instead views the change as being caused by many factors, not just one or even a few. Those dharmas which arise from a cause, the TathÄgata has declared their cause. And that which is the cessation of them, thus the great renunciant (sramana) has taught. Through ignorance, karma is accumulated, karma is the cause of (re)birth. Through knowledge, karma is not accumulated, through absence of karma, one is not (re)born. The additional verse is Southeast Asia specific (fifth century date) and does not have an equivalent in any Buddhist text, whether in the original Indic language or Tibetan or Chinese translation. Guggul resin. Mustard seeds1. Saffron. Eco-friendly red paint. Life force pillar2. Body, speech, and mind pills3. A loose pearl. Relics. Gemstone powder: Diamond Green turquoise Red coral Ruby Mother of pearl Carnelian Blue apatite Obsidian Five metal powder: Gold Silver Copper Zinc Iron Five seed powder: Barley Black sesame Yellow mustard Peas Wheat Gemstones. Maá¹‡á¸ala wheels. Holy pills. Medicinal, herbal & incense powder. Juniper powder. Nice cotton cloth or silk with saffron or deity specific color. Statue/stupa copper seal (if it didn't come with it). Eco-friendly universal glue. Epoxy putty. Paintbrush. Prayer rolls: Head (body) prayer roll Throat (speech) prayer roll Upper body prayer roll Heart (mind) prayer roll Deity specific prayer roll 100 syllables prayer roll (more details) Rib prayer roll Lower body prayer roll Dependent origination prayer roll (more details) Five purification prayer roll (more details) Correction prayer roll Various auspiciousness verse rolls Lotus prayer roll Six dharmakÄya relics prayer roll (more details) Heart of the perfection wisdom prayer roll (more details) Wealth deity prayer roll (more details)

The video shows how to fill Buddha statue. The essential prayers for holy objects will explain further on the topic. We bless all the supplies, including the statue/stupa itself. Wrap the statue's face in cotton wool carefully to protect the painting. We pick any leftover resin inside the statue/stupa with a screwdriver or similar tool. We need to unblock the neck, smoothen the hole, break off, or file down any small metal protrusions, to reduce the number of obstructions to put the prayer rolls inside. We clean the inside of the statue/stupa thoroughly with nice scented soap and water, rinse it well with water, and allow it to dry. We burn Guggul resin underneath the statue/stupa and simultaneously throw the mustard seeds to remove negativity. Rinse the inside of the statue/stupa with saffron water, and allow it to dry. Paint the inside of the statue/stupa with a red color. While the paint is still wet, sprinkle some five metal powder, gemstone powder, and medicinal, herbal & incense powder. Allow the paint to dry before filling the statue/stupa. Fill the statue/stupa by inserting the appropriate prayers and substances in the correct order and in the correct places: Body (white) pill, a loose pearl, relics, head prayer roll (Buddha statue only), and five purification prayer roll. Speech (red) pill, throat prayer roll (Buddha statue only), and five purification prayer roll. Slide in the life force pillar face forward. Mind (blue), amá¹›ta, and maá¹‡i pills, upper body, heart, and deity prayer rolls (Buddha statue only), 100 syllables prayer roll. Amá¹›ta and maá¹‡i pills, rib and heart prayer rolls (Buddha statue only), and five purification prayer roll. Lower body prayer roll (Buddha statue only), and Dependent origination prayer roll. Correction, various auspiciousness verse, and five purification prayer rolls. Six dharmakÄya relics, Heart of the perfection wisdom, Wealth deity, lotus prayer rolls. After we fill each layer of the statue/stupa, we pack tightly medicinal, herbal & incense powder amongst prayer rolls, filling every space. We put juniper powder, five metal powder, gemstone powder, gemstones, and five seeds powder. Finally, place the five maá¹‡á¸ala wheels with Jambhala on the top (towards the Buddha statue head or the top of the stupa) and the heads of the deities directed towards the back of the statue/stupa. The ViÅ›vavajra faces down toward the base of the statue/stupa like Jambhala. (so if they "stood up", they would face the same direction as the statue/stupa). Cover everything with a saffron cloth, then close with eco-friendly glue, and seal the base of the statue/stupa with epoxy putty, so that no insects can gain access. When filling a small statue/stupa wherein all the listed prayer rolls will not fit, the six dharmakÄya relics and the five purification prayer rolls can be used throughout. The six dharmakÄya relics prayer rolls to be used as much as possible. ye dharmÄ hetuprabhavÄ hetuá¹ƒ teá¹£Äá¹ƒ tathÄgata uvÄca à¥¤ teá¹£Äá¹ƒ-ca yo nirodha evaá¹ƒvÄdi mahÄÅ›ramaá¹‡aá¸¥ à¥¤ ajÃ±ÄnÄc cÄ«yate karma janmanaá¸¥ karma kÄraá¹‡am à¥¤ jÃ±ÄnÄn na cÄ«yate karma karmÄbhÄvÄn na jÄyateà¥¥ 7x Dependent origination can be contrasted with the classic Western concept of causation in which an action by one thing is said to cause a change in another thing. Dependent origination instead views the change as being caused by many factors, not just one or even a few. Those dharmas which arise from a cause, the TathÄgata has declared their cause. And that which is the cessation of them, thus the great renunciant (sramana) has taught. Through ignorance, karma is accumulated, karma is the cause of (re)birth. Through knowledge, karma is not accumulated, through absence of karma, one is not (re)born. The additional verse is Southeast Asia specific (fifth century date) and does not have an equivalent in any Buddhist text, whether in the original Indic language or Tibetan or Chinese translation. Maá¹‡á¸ala wheels strip (double sided, flip on short edge) or maá¹‡á¸ala wheels Jambhala maá¹‡á¸ala wheel. VasudhÄrÄ maá¹‡á¸ala wheel. Ganapati maá¹‡á¸ala wheel. Aá¹£á¹­amaá¹…gala maá¹‡á¸ala wheel. ViÅ›vavajra maá¹‡á¸ala wheel. Honey. Butter. Sugar. Gemstones powder: Diamond Green turquoise Red coral Ruby Mother of pearl Carnelian Blue apatite Obsidian Red and white sandalwood. Nice cotton cloth or silk with saffron or deity specific color.

Use a mixture of honey, butter, and sugar together with the gemstones powder, red and white sandalwood (sweet paste offering) to stick the Jambhala and VasudhÄrÄ maá¹‡á¸ala wheel together - as if they were embracing - with Jambhala on top facing downwards. After they are stuck together, make sure to mark the outside of the maá¹‡á¸ala wheels to identify both Jambhala and the placement of the heads of the deities. When the maá¹‡á¸ala wheels are placed inside the statue/stupa, Jambhala will be on the top and the heads of the deities will be directed towards the back of the statue/stupa (as if they "stood up", they would be facing the same direction as the statue/stupa). Beneath the VasudhÄrÄ maá¹‡á¸ala wheel, add the Ganapati maá¹‡á¸ala wheel, the Aá¹£á¹­amaá¹…gala maá¹‡á¸ala wheel (both facing up), and finally the ViÅ›vavajra maá¹‡á¸ala wheel. The ViÅ›vavajra maá¹‡á¸ala wheel faces down toward the statue/stupa's base like Jambhala maá¹‡á¸ala wheel. These can all be stuck together with the sweet paste offering. Wrap all of them together with a nice cloth.

Prayer strips on saffron color paper (e.g. Ä€ryatÄrÄ prayer strips: Buddha statue/stupa, prayer wheel; or prayer wheel life force pillar). A pure incense stick (coreless). Thin cotton cloth or lama's robe (saffron or deity specific color). A paper glue stick. Eco-friendly red dye or marker. A scissors. An oblong block of wood.

The video shows how to roll prayer strips. More videos with wider prayer strips. The essential prayers for holy objects will explain further on the topic. Cut off a piece of pure incense stick to the width of the prayer strip. Roll the first sheet with the pure incense stick glued inside, beginning at the "head" (start) of the text, which faces inwards. Hold the top and bottom of the pure incense stick to roll it easier. Additional strips are then added with the same orientation, in groups of one or more - depending upon our dexterity, with an overlap of about 2 cm towards the end of the previous strips. Tighten the prayer roll by rolling them on a firm surface with an oblong block of wood. Finish the roll with a single strip, gluing firmly the final 2 cm. Mark the top of the prayer roll with red dye or marker. Wrap the outside of the prayer roll with cloth to the exact width of the prayer roll. Glue the cloth all around and over the junction of its ends. Write the prayer name and the repetition numbers on a small piece of paper and glue that outside of the prayer roll.

The steps to roll prayer strips for prayer wheel is almost the same as the one for Buddha statue/stupa. Except we roll the strip to face outwards without the pure incense stick and use the gap to slide in the prayer roll to prayer wheel rod. Roll the first prayer strip with the prayer wheel life force pillar strip or prayer wheel strip for smaller prayer wheel, and subsequent with the Buddha statue/stupa prayer strip. (e.g. Ä€ryatÄrÄ prayer wheel strips and Buddha statue/stupa prayer strips) Place the earth wheel on the bottom of the prayer roll facing up and the sky wheel on the top facing down.

ye dharmÄ hetuprabhavÄ hetuá¹ƒ teá¹£Äá¹ƒ tathÄgata uvÄca à¥¤ teá¹£Äá¹ƒ-ca yo nirodha evaá¹ƒvÄdi mahÄÅ›ramaá¹‡aá¸¥ à¥¤ ajÃ±ÄnÄc cÄ«yate karma janmanaá¸¥ karma kÄraá¹‡am à¥¤ jÃ±ÄnÄn na cÄ«yate karma karmÄbhÄvÄn na jÄyateà¥¥ 7x Dependent origination can be contrasted with the classic Western concept of causation in which an action by one thing is said to cause a change in another thing. Dependent origination instead views the change as being caused by many factors, not just one or even a few. Those dharmas which arise from a cause, the TathÄgata has declared their cause. And that which is the cessation of them, thus the great renunciant (sramana) has taught. Through ignorance, karma is accumulated, karma is the cause of (re)birth. Through knowledge, karma is not accumulated, through absence of karma, one is not (re)born. The additional verse is Southeast Asia specific (fifth century date) and does not have an equivalent in any Buddhist text, whether in the original Indic language or Tibetan or Chinese translation.
